question_paper.question_paper_name: IIT M DAD DP QUALIFIER EXAM QPA 07 Aug 2022 IBA NS
question_paper.question_paper_description: 2022 Aug: IIT M DAD DP QUALIFIER EXAM

questions.question_text_1: Anil started walking 400 meters straight from his office. He then turned right and walked 300 meters. He turned right and walked another 100 meters to reach his house. If his house is South-East from his office, then in which direction did Anil start walking from the office?
question_texts: Anil started walking 400 meters straight from his office. He then turned right and walked 300 meters. He turned right and walked another 100 meters to reach his house. If his house is South-East from his office, then in which direction did Anil start walking from the office?

questions.question_text_1: Ram is 16th from the left end in a row of boys and Shyam is 12th from the right end. If Shyam is immediate left of Ram, then how many boys are there in the row?
question_texts: Ram is 16th from the left end in a row of boys and Shyam is 12th from the right end. If Shyam is immediate left of Ram, then how many boys are there in the row?

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following years is not a leap year?
question_texts: Which of the following years is not a leap year?

questions.question_text_1: The Chairman of the selection committee arrived at 14:00 h for conducting an interview. He came 20 minutes before the other members of the board, who were 30 minutes late for the interview. At what time was the interview scheduled?
question_texts: The Chairman of the selection committee arrived at 14:00 h for conducting an interview. He came 20 minutes before the other members of the board, who were 30 minutes late for the interview. At what time was the interview scheduled?

questions.question_text_1: In a certain code language, if ONLINE can be written as LMORMV, then how can PROGRAM be written?
question_texts: In a certain code language, if ONLINE can be written as LMORMV, then how can PROGRAM be written?

questions.question_text_1: Suppose there are 4 members in a family. A is daughter of B. C is sister of D who is the son of B. How is C. related to A?
question_texts: Suppose there are 4 members in a family. A is daughter of B. C is sister of D who is the son of B. How is C. related to A?

questions.question_text_1: If in a particular leap year 6th January is Sunday, then what day will be on 26th April of the same year?
question_texts: If in a particular leap year 6th January is Sunday, then what day will be on 26th April of the same year?

questions.question_text_1: Two statements are given followed by two conclusions I and II. You have to consider the statements to be true even if they seem to contradict commonly known facts. You have to decide which of the given conclusions follows from the given statements. Statements: • All cats are dogs. • All cats are white. Conclusions:  I. All dogs are white. II. Some dogs are not white.
question_texts: Two statements are given followed by two conclusions I and II. You have to consider the statements to be true even if they seem to contradict commonly known facts. You have to decide which of the given conclusions follows from the given statements. Statements: • All cats are dogs. • All cats are white. Conclusions:  I. All dogs are white. II. Some dogs are not white.

options.option_text: Neither conclusion I nor conclusion II.

questions.question_text_1: Suppose one page is torn from a booklet whose pages are numbered in the usual manner starting from the first page as 1. If the sum of the numbers on the remaining pages is 44, then the torn page contains which of the following numbers?
question_texts: Suppose one page is torn from a booklet whose pages are numbered in the usual manner starting from the first page as 1. If the sum of the numbers on the remaining pages is 44, then the torn page contains which of the following numbers?

questions.question_text_1: In a certain code language, ‘lo ka pi bi’ means ‘direct entry to diploma’, ‘bi lu ko ka’ means ‘exam for direct entry’, ‘lu ka se pi’ means ‘diploma level entry exam’. Which word in that language means ‘exam’?
question_texts: In a certain code language, ‘lo ka pi bi’ means ‘direct entry to diploma’, ‘bi lu ko ka’ means ‘exam for direct entry’, ‘lu ka se pi’ means ‘diploma level entry exam’. Which word in that language means ‘exam’?

questions.question_text_1: A bottle contains 16 litres of liquid S. 4 litres of liquid S is taken out of it and replaced same quantity of liquid L. Again 4 litres of the mixture is taken out and replaced by same quantity of liquid L. What is the ratio of quantity of liquid L to that of liquid S in the final mixture?
question_texts: A bottle contains 16 litres of liquid S. 4 litres of liquid S is taken out of it and replaced same quantity of liquid L. Again 4 litres of the mixture is taken out and replaced by same quantity of liquid L. What is the ratio of quantity of liquid L to that of liquid S in the final mixture?

questions.question_text_1: A frog tries to come out of a dried well which is 5 meters deep with slippery walls. Every time the frog jumps 20 cm, it slides down 6 cm. What is the number of jumps required for the frog to come out of the well?
question_texts: A frog tries to come out of a dried well which is 5 meters deep with slippery walls. Every time the frog jumps 20 cm, it slides down 6 cm. What is the number of jumps required for the frog to come out of the well?

questions.question_text_1: Two statements S1 and S2 are given below with regard to two numbers followed by a question.  Statements: S1: Their product is 21. S2: Their sum is 10. Question: What are the two numbers? Which of the following is true with respect to the above statements and the question?
question_texts: Two statements S1 and S2 are given below with regard to two numbers followed by a question.  Statements: S1: Their product is 21. S2: Their sum is 10. Question: What are the two numbers? Which of the following is true with respect to the above statements and the question?

options.option_text: S1 alone is sufficient to answer the question.
S2 alone is sufficient to answer the question.
S1 and S2 together are sufficient to answer the question.
S1 and S2 together are not sufficient to answer the question.

questions.question_text_1: In adult population of a city, 50% men and 40% women are married. If no man marries more than one woman and no woman marries more than one man and no two from the same gender marry each other, and there are no widows and widowers, then what is the percentage of married adult population?
question_texts: In adult population of a city, 50% men and 40% women are married. If no man marries more than one woman and no woman marries more than one man and no two from the same gender marry each other, and there are no widows and widowers, then what is the percentage of married adult population?

questions.question_text_1: Study the information carefully and answer the given subquestions:  Zaitoon, a multi cuisine restaurant stays open every Monday to Saturday but is closed on all Sundays. In every week, lunch is served only on Monday, Tuesday and Friday. On Wednesdays, Thursdays and Saturdays, just dinner is served. The restaurant’s floors are polished and plants are watered only on these six days, according to the following schedule: • Plants are watered two days each week, but never on consecutive days and never on the same day that floors are polished. • Floors are polished on Monday and two other days each week, but never on consecutive days and never on the same day that plants are watered.
question_texts: Study the information carefully and answer the given subquestions:  Zaitoon, a multi cuisine restaurant stays open every Monday to Saturday but is closed on all Sundays. In every week, lunch is served only on Monday, Tuesday and Friday. On Wednesdays, Thursdays and Saturdays, just dinner is served. The restaurant’s floors are polished and plants are watered only on these six days, according to the following schedule: • Plants are watered two days each week, but never on consecutive days and never on the same day that floors are polished. • Floors are polished on Monday and two other days each week, but never on consecutive days and never on the same day that plants are watered.

questions.question_text_1: According to a schedule, the restaurant’s floors are polished on either _______
question_texts: According to a schedule, the restaurant’s floors are polished on either _______

props.summary:
Here’s a structured **summary of core topics, concepts, and principles** for the **"Qualifier: Aptitude"** exam, along with a **Mermaid knowledge graph** to visualize relationships.

---

### **Core Topics & Concepts**
#### **1. Logical Reasoning & Puzzles**
- **Direction Sense**: Movement in cardinal directions (N/S/E/W) with turns.
  - Example: Anil’s walking path (Q2).
- **Family Relations**: Blood relations (siblings, parents, cousins).
  - Example: Family tree (Q8).
- **Seating Arrangement/Positioning**:
  - Rank-based positioning (left/right) (Q3).
- **Venn Diagrams/Set Theory**:
  - Overlapping sets (Teachers/Students/Authors) (Q6).
- **Coding-Decoding**:
  - Letter substitution (e.g., ONLINE → LMORMV) (Q7, Q12).
- **Syllogism**:
  - Logical deductions from statements (e.g., "All cats are dogs") (Q10).

#### **2. Mathematical Aptitude**
- **Arithmetic**:
  - **Leap Years**: Rules (divisible by 4, 100, 400) (Q4).
  - **Time Calculations**: Scheduling (e.g., interview timing) (Q5).
  - **Page Number Summation**: Missing page in a book (Q11).
- **Algebra**:
  - **System of Equations**: Solving for 2 variables (sum/product) (Q15).
- **Mixtures & Ratios**:
  - **Replacement Problems**: Liquid ratios after replacements (Q13).
- **Progressions**:
  - **Frog’s Well Problem**: Net progress per jump (20 cm up, 6 cm down) (Q14).
- **Percentages**:
  - **Marriage Statistics**: % of married adults (Q16).

#### **3. Data Interpretation & Scheduling**
- **Calendar Problems**:
  - Day of the week given a leap year (Q9).
- **Scheduling Constraints**:
  - Restaurant operations (lunch/dinner, polishing/watering) (Q17–Q21).
  - Non-consecutive days, mutual exclusivity (e.g., no polishing + watering on same day).

#### **4. Verbal Reasoning**
- **Statement-Conclusion**:
  - Validating conclusions from premises (Q10).
- **Word Coding**:
  - Deciphering language rules (Q7, Q12).

---

### **Key Equations & Rules**
1. **Leap Year Rule**:
   - Divisible by 4 **but not** by 100 (unless also divisible by 400).
   - *Example*: 1900 is **not** a leap year (Q4).

2. **Net Progress (Frog’s Well)**:
   - Net gain per jump = `20 cm (up) - 6 cm (down) = 14 cm`.
   - Total jumps = `(Total height - Initial jump) / Net gain + 1`.
   - *Equation*: \( \text{Jumps} = \frac{500 - 20}{14} + 1 = 36 \) (Q14).

3. **Mixture Ratio (Replacement)**:
   - After 2 replacements of 4L in 16L:
     - Remaining liquid S = \( 16 \times \left(1 - \frac{4}{16}\right)^2 = 9 \)L.
     - Ratio L:S = `7:9` (Q13).

4. **Married Population %**:
   - Let \( M = \text{men}, W = \text{women} \).
   - Married men = 50% of \( M \), married women = 40% of \( W \).
   - Since marriages are 1:1, \( 0.5M = 0.4W \).
   - Total married = \( 0.5M + 0.4W = 0.8W \) (if \( M = 0.8W \)).
   - % married = \( \frac{0.8W}{M + W} \times 100 = 44.\overline{4}\% \) (Q16).

5. **Page Number Sum**:
   - Sum of first \( n \) pages = \( \frac{n(n+1)}{2} \).
   - Torn page sum = \( \text{Total sum} - 44 = 5 + 6 = 11 \) (Q11).

6. **Direction to Coordinates**:
   - South-East implies initial direction was **East** (Q2).

---

### **Mermaid Knowledge Graphs**
#### **Graph 1: Logical Reasoning & Puzzles**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Logical Reasoning] --> B[Direction Sense]
    A --> C[Family Relations]
    A --> D[Seating Arrangement]
    A --> E[Venn Diagrams]
    A --> F[Coding-Decoding]
    A --> G[Syllogism]

    B --> H["Cardinal Directions\n(N/S/E/W)"]
    B --> I["Turns (Left/Right)"]
    C --> J["Siblings, Parents, Cousins"]
    D --> K["Rank-Based Positioning"]
    E --> L["Overlapping Sets\n(Teachers/Students/Authors)"]
    F --> M["Letter Substitution\n(ONLINE → LMORMV)"]
    G --> N["Premise → Conclusion\n(All cats are dogs)"]
```

#### **Graph 2: Mathematical Aptitude**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Mathematical Aptitude] --> B[Arithmetic]
    A --> C[Algebra]
    A --> D[Mixtures & Ratios]
    A --> E[Progressions]
    A --> F[Percentages]

    B --> G["Leap Years\n(divisible by 4/100/400)"]
    B --> H["Time Calculations\n(Interview Scheduling)"]
    B --> I["Page Summation\n(Torn Page)"]
    C --> J["System of Equations\n(Sum/Product)"]
    D --> K["Replacement Problems\n(Liquid Ratios)"]
    E --> L["Frog's Well\n(Net Progress)"]
    F --> M["Marriage Statistics\n(44.44% Married)"]
```

#### **Graph 3: Data Interpretation & Scheduling**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Data Interpretation] --> B[Calendar Problems]
    A --> C[Scheduling Constraints]

    B --> D["Day of Week\n(Leap Year)"]
    C --> E["Restaurant Operations\n(Lunch/Dinner)"]
    C --> F["Polishing/Watering\n(Non-Consecutive Days)"]
    C --> G["Mutual Exclusivity\n(No Polishing + Watering)"]
```

#### **Graph 4: Verbal Reasoning**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Verbal Reasoning] --> B[Statement-Conclusion]
    A --> C[Word Coding]

    B --> D["Validating Conclusions\n(All cats are dogs → ?)"]
    C --> E["Deciphering Rules\n(lo ka pi bi = ?)"]
```

---
### **Exam Preparation Tips**
1. **Practice Direction Sense**: Draw diagrams for movement problems (Q2).
2. **Master Venn Diagrams**: Use set theory for overlapping categories (Q6).
3. **Memorize Leap Year Rules**: Quickly identify non-leap years (Q4).
4. **Solve Mixture Problems**: Use replacement formulas (Q13).
5. **Calendar Calculations**: Count days from a reference date (Q9).
6. **Logical Deduction**: Eliminate invalid conclusions (Q10).
7. **Scheduling Constraints**: Use tables for restaurant problems (Q17–Q21).
